documentType: Bureau of Prisons psychology services clinical notes
summary: A series of Bureau of Prisons psychology service clinical notes documenting daily mental status evaluations of inmate Jeffrey Epstein from July 27-31, 2019, while he was on psychological observation following an incident involving marks on his neck. The notes assess his competency for a disciplinary process and document his adjustment to Special Housing Unit (SHU) conditions. This document contains a series of Bureau of Prisons psychology service clinical notes and reports regarding Jeffrey Epstein's mental health status and suicide risk assessments while incarcerated at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York in July 2019. The notes detail his placement on and removal from suicide watch after an incident involving a string around his neck, his psychological observations, his complaints about confinement conditions, and his interactions with staff and his cellmate. A series of Bureau of Prisons psychology service records documenting the mental health assessment and monitoring of Jeffrey Epstein while incarcerated at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York in July 2019. The records include suicide risk assessments, clinical contacts, and administrative notes, culminating in the incident on July 23, 2019, where Epstein was found with a string around his neck and placed on suicide watch. This document is a Bureau of Prisons Suicide Risk Assessment for Jeffrey Epstein conducted on July 9, 2019, the day after a court proceeding. It details his psychological evaluation, risk factors, and concludes his acute suicide risk is low. The assessment was made in response to his high-profile case and recent court appearance. This document contains Bureau of Prisons psychological assessments of Jeffrey Epstein conducted on July 8-10, 2019, while he was incarcerated at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York (MCC-NY). It includes suicide risk assessments, intake screening, and risk of sexual abusiveness evaluation, all concluding Epstein was at low risk with no acute psychopathology. The assessments note his positive outlook regarding his legal case and future orientation.

persons.name: Jeffrey Edward Epstein
persons.context: The subject of all clinical notes, undergoing psychological observation and evaluation for competency regarding a disciplinary incident (tattooing/self-mutilation charge). He reports sleep issues, anxiety about returning to SHU, and cannot recall how marks appeared on his neck.

persons.name: Proto
persons.context: Referred inmate Epstein for a competency evaluation regarding the disciplinary process for incident report number 3282555.

persons.name: PsyD/DAPC
persons.context: Clinical psychologist who conducted several follow-up sessions with Epstein, documented his mental status, and provided supportive interventions.

persons.name: PhD/Chief Psychologist
persons.context: The chief psychologist who conducted multiple clinical contacts and administrative notes with Epstein, addressing his complaints about conditions in SHU and assessing his mental status.

persons.name: SHU Lt.
persons.context: Informed that Mr. Epstein needed to be housed with an appropriate cellmate upon return to the Special Housing Unit.

persons.name: Nick
persons.context: Epstein's former cellmate in the SHU. Epstein asks to speak with him to see if he can provide information about the incident that led to the marks on Epstein's neck.

persons.name: PsyD
persons.context: A psychologist (Doctor of Psychology) who conducted a suicide risk assessment on Epstein on July 23, 2019, after he was found with a string around his neck.

persons.name: Ph.D.
persons.context: The provider listed on the Post Suicide Watch Report dated July 24, 2019. Likely the same individual as the 'PhD/Chief Psychologist'.

persons.name: Operations Lt.
persons.context: The operations lieutenant who contacted the on-call psychologist at about 2 AM on July 23, 2019, to inform them Epstein was being placed on suicide watch.

persons.name: SHU lieutenant
persons.context: A lieutenant in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) whom the chief psychologist informed about Epstein's concerns regarding soap, a spoon, and phone calls.

persons.name: Epstein's brother
persons.context: Mentioned by Epstein as his only family, with whom he does not have a close relationship. This is noted as a static risk factor (lack of family connections).

persons.name: Epstein's attorney
persons.context: Epstein expressed confidence in his attorney, describing him as 'competent,' and requested to meet with him. The attorney is not named.

persons.name: PsyD/PhD
persons.context: Conducted intake screening and risk of sexual abusiveness assessment for Jeffrey Epstein on July 8, 2019.

connections.description: Unit Manager Proto referred Epstein for a competency evaluation regarding a disciplinary process.
Clinical psychologist providing daily mental status evaluations and therapeutic interventions to inmate Epstein.
Chief Psychologist consulted on Epstein's case and conducted at least one clinical session with him.
Epstein was previously housed in a double-cell with Nick in the SHU. Epstein claims Nick called him a 'pedophile' and was reading a newspaper article about him prior to the neck incident.
The psychologist conducted daily clinical interviews with Epstein while he was on psychological observation, providing supportive interventions and assessing his mental status.
Clinical therapeutic relationship; the chief psychologist conducted multiple assessment and support sessions with inmate Epstein.
Clinical assessment relationship; the psychologist conducted a formal suicide risk assessment on Epstein after the July 23 incident.
Custodial and security relationship; the lieutenant was involved in the decision to place Epstein on suicide watch.
Epstein identified his brother as his only family but stated they do not have a close relationship.
Epstein has an attorney whom he trusts and described as competent. He requested a meeting with him.
The psychologist conducted a clinical interview and suicide risk assessment of inmate Epstein.
Psychologist conducted suicide risk assessment and psychological observation of inmate Epstein.
Psychologist conducted intake screening and sexual abusiveness risk assessment for inmate Epstein.

events.title: Epstein charged with tattooing/self-mutilation
events.description: Inmate Epstein was charged with BOP code 228 (Tattooing or Self-Mutilation), assigned incident report number 3282555, leading to marks on his neck.

events.title: Competency evaluation for disciplinary process
events.description: Psychological evaluation determined Epstein was competent to proceed with the disciplinary process regarding the July 23 incident.

events.title: Follow-up after removal from psychological observation
events.description: Epstein seen for follow-up after being removed from Psychological Observation the previous day; reported going to court for a status hearing.

events.title: Epstein requests to stay in hospital area
events.description: Epstein asked to remain in the hospital area where he felt 'safe' for an entire week but was told he would return to SHU after receiving his CPAP machine.

events.title: Epstein Found with String Around Neck
events.description: Epstein is found in his SHU cell with a string loosely tied around his neck in the early morning hours. He is placed on suicide watch. He later tells staff his cellmate tried to kill him, but claims no memory of the event to psychologists.

events.title: Removal from Suicide Watch
events.description: Epstein is stepped down from suicide watch to psychological observation after a risk assessment. He adamantly denies suicidality, expresses a commitment to fighting his legal case, and describes having a 'wonderful life'.

events.title: Daily Psychological Observation
events.description: Epstein remains on psychological observation in the hospital area. He is in good spirits, engages in legal visits, interacts with inmate companions, but continues to report no memory of the neck incident and complains about SHU conditions.

events.title: Suicide Risk Assessment
events.description: A psychologist conducted a formal suicide risk assessment on Epstein after the incident. The assessment concluded with a 'Moderate' overall acute suicide risk and 'Absent' chronic risk, recommending continued suicide watch.

events.title: Placed in Administrative Detention/SHU
events.description: Epstein was placed in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) under 'Administrative Detention' status.

events.title: Court Proceeding / Bail Denial
events.description: Referenced in notes; Epstein returned from court on the evening of July 8, and it is noted he was recently denied bail, which is listed as a risk factor.

events.title: Initial Psychological Assessment
events.description: Epstein was seen for a precautionary suicide risk assessment after returning from court. He was found psychologically stable with no diagnosis and no acute risk.

events.title: Epstein's Court Proceeding
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein returned from a court proceeding in the evening. The assessment notes this could have given him 'bad news regarding his legal situation,' prompting his placement on precautionary psychological observation.

events.title: Suicide Risk Assessment
events.description: A Bureau of Prisons psychologist conducted a suicide risk assessment on Jeffrey Epstein at 7:30 a.m. He was found to have a low acute suicide risk and was not placed on suicide watch.

events.title: Amendment to Health Note
events.description: An amendment was made to a health services note by the PhD/Chief Psychologist at 10:40 a.m.

events.title: Previous Incarceration in Palm Beach
events.description: Epstein reported having previously served time in Palm Beach County jail on charges of soliciting prostitution.

events.title: Court proceeding for Epstein
events.description: Epstein had a court proceeding that could potentially give him bad news regarding his legal situation, prompting psychological monitoring.

events.title: Psychological observation of Epstein
events.description: Comprehensive psychological assessment found Epstein with normal mental status, no acute psychopathology, and low suicide risk.

events.title: Intake screening and risk assessment
events.description: Initial psychological intake screening and risk of sexual abusiveness assessment conducted on Epstein upon arrival at MCC-NY.

locations: SHU (Special Housing Unit) at MCC New York
Hospital/Psychological Observation area at MCC New York
SHU (Special Housing Unit within MCC New York)
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was found competent to proceed with a disciplinary process for a charge of 'Tattooing or Self-Mutilation' (code 228) from July 23, 2019.
Epstein repeatedly stated he could not remember how marks appeared on his neck, suggesting possible memory impairment from sleep apnea or the incident itself.
Clinical notes document Epstein's significant sleep disturbances, anxiety about noise in SHU, and his adjustment to prison conditions in the days leading up to his death.
Epstein explicitly denied current and past suicidal ideation, intent, or plans during multiple evaluations in late July 2019.
The documents show coordination between psychology staff, unit management, and medical regarding Epstein's housing, safety, and healthcare needs.
On July 23, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his SHU cell with a string loosely tied around his neck, leading to his placement on suicide watch.
Epstein repeatedly claimed to have no memory of how the string got around his neck, offering vague accounts of getting water and waking up to his own snoring.
Epstein told staff that his cellmate 'Nick' tried to kill him, but later denied remembering the incident or any threats from the cellmate.
Clinical psychologists assessed Epstein's suicide risk as low and stepped him down to psychological observation by July 24, noting he was future-oriented and invested in his legal case.

Epstein expressed significant complaints about conditions in the SHU, including noise, smells, restrictions, and fear for his safety, preferring general population or continued psychological observation.
On July 23, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his SHU cell with a string loosely tied around his neck; he claimed no memory of the event, and it was unclear if he or someone else placed it there.

A suicide risk assessment conducted that same day assessed Epstein's overall acute suicide risk as 'Moderate' and chronic risk as 'Absent,' citing risk factors like his high-profile crime, sex offender status, and lack of family connections.
Epstein consistently denied any past or present suicidal ideation, intention, or plans during all psychological evaluations in July 2019.
The documents show Epstein was actively engaged with his legal team, had recently been denied bail, and expressed future plans to 'fight his case and go back to his normal life.'
Epstein made numerous complaints about his conditions in SHU, including lack of property, cold cells, uniform issues, and access to phone calls and medical items like Colace.
On July 9, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was assessed as having a 'Low' acute suicide risk and 'Absent' chronic suicide risk by Bureau of Prisons psychology staff.
Epstein was placed on psychological observation as a precaution after returning from a court proceeding on July 8, 2019, but was not on suicide watch.
Epstein denied any history of suicidal ideation, mental health treatment, or substance abuse, and presented as calm, cooperative, and future-oriented during the assessment.
Identified risk factors for suicidality included his high-profile case, sex offense charges, pre-trial status, and lack of close family connections (only a brother).
The assessment was conducted the day before Epstein's reported death, and it concluded a suicide watch was 'not warranted at this time.'

On July 9, 2019, a Bureau of Prisons psychologist assessed Jeffrey Epstein as having no acute psychopathology, a clear mental status, and low overall suicide risk despite having high-profile sex offense charges.
Epstein was described as future-oriented, cooperative, with a positive outlook on his legal case, and he explicitly denied any suicidal ideation, intention, or plan.

A separate assessment on July 8, 2019, identified Epstein as being at low risk of sexual abusiveness in the prison setting, though he had a history of prior sexual abuse perpetration in the community.
The documents show psychological monitoring was initiated due to Epstein's high-profile case, sex offense charges, and a court proceeding that might bring bad legal news.
Epstein was classified as CARE1-MH, indicating no significant functional impairment from mental illness and no need for regular mental health intervention.
